transcripts.text: You've had a lot of experience developing artists, finding artists.  Yeah.  I was reading L.A.  Reid's book, and he talked about all the misses he had, where he regrets this person or that person.  What are the misses you had?

I've had a ton of misses.  What people don't see is the misses.  You know, my family, I say this all the time.  I got a goddaughter, Ricky, she's in the business, and she always is like, you just keep, you're doing it, uncle, you're doing it.  I said, Ricky, because you don't see the thousand no's.  You just hear the one.  yes.  Right.  But I said, I don't wear the nose, because I'm gonna run through that.  In this business, you have to have... It was a good conversation.  I was with Jimmy Iovine and, uh, Zane, Zane Lowe.  He does the thing.  He was in there.  And me and Jimmy... We think alike.  I love talking to Jimmy because he's fearless how I am.  So we was talking about new artists and putting them out and going for it.  And Zayn was like, yo, but what if that fails?  Like, I'm not scared if it fails.  And Jimmy was like, no.  I'm just gonna try it again with somebody else.  And that's just my mindset.  Like, I have made some mistakes.  I have definitely failed a million times.
What's the biggest mistake?
J-Lo.  Mm.
How so?

I talked... crazy about her in Elle magazine when she asked me to do... give them quotes, because she was on the cover.  This was around the time with I'm Real and Ain't It Funny.  Mm-hmm.  Man.  So, I was high.  I was on, like... probably three ecstasy pills, which was the daily.  That was like breakfast.  You know what I'm saying?  For, like, three years, I was... That was high.  All of those great records, though, we made highs and motherfuckers.  Right?  So not saying to do that, children.  Don't do it.  That's just me.  You know what I'm saying?  So I got off the phone.  I got into an argument with Tommy Mottola about Ain't It Funny, about Cadillac Ty, and them not servicing the record with Cadillac Ty on it.  So I'm going in on Tommy.  Tommy says some shit.  So I'm on 10.  Like, I'm telling Tommy, when I see you, I'm you up.  Tommy's my good friend now.  Right.  Yeah, it's all good.
I got over it, right.

Yeah, it's all good.  But at that moment, it was when I see you, I'm you up.  And I don't care what happens.  I'll do the bid.  You can throw me.  But you're going to get your ass whipped, right?  So I hang the phone up in literally two minutes.  It's while I'm on 10 and high, which is not a good mixture.  So the phone rings, and it's Elle magazine.  And they said, we want to get some quotes, you and J-Lo.  And I said, wow.  And she didn't deserve that, because J-Lo was like one of my.  What did you say?  I knew he was going to ask that.  They asked if I'm Real was about Diddy.  And J-Lo told them it wasn't.  And I was like.  Yes, it is.  And I call her the B word.  Like an idiot.  I was like, that bitch is lying or whatever.  Have y'all ever healed from that?  No.  Did she call you?  I send her flowers and roses and I apologize and I will continue to apologize for the rest of my life and I will say I'm a fucking idiot.  But if she never trusts me again, I can't blame her.  I'm an idiot.  Like, that one, that's my biggest regret.
Do you feel like you left a lot of money on the table or a situation could have really happened with Jay-Z, DMX, and Ja Rule?

I mean, with that, it was more... That wasn't my fault.  That was just egos and... individuals, and it just didn't come together.  You know, I left a lot of money on the table, though, with the feds.  Like, the feds me over.  When the feds raided me January 3rd, 2003, if you look at my history, Ashanti was selling, like, six, seven million.  Ja was selling, like, six, seven million.  I was doing, like, for two years, I was doing, like, 120 million in business.  and billing, right?  So I was due, like, a $60 million to $70 million check, because I owned half of that money was supposed to come to me.  So when the feds raided, it was a strategic move on them.  If you look at the dates, I didn't go to court and trial till two and a half years later.  But they did that because they knew I'm about to get $60 million.  Mm.  For the sales.  So when they raided me, like, a week after they raided, they sent a letter to the Universal Music Group, said, if you give Irving Lorenzo $1, you're gonna be his co-defendant, because you gave him all this money that he's praying with.
Right.  Mm, yeah.
To which that gave Universal Music Group, they're happy.  Or if we can't give you anything.  We can't give you anything.

Yeah, yeah, yeah.  Wow.  Right.  How did you manage it?  Because you talk about doing pills, uh, things like that throughout the day.  And you said that was like breakfast.  How did you deal with that kind of stress?  I mean, how...
What, the feds?
Yeah, like, because you had to manage that.  You had to fight the government.
The drugs wasn't... I wasn't doing drugs because of the feds.
No, no, I'm just wondering, did that affect how you... Like, how did you manage that mentally?
A lot of God.  It brought me closer to God.  Listening to Mary J. Blige, My Life.
Yes, My Life.
Which is an episode on Tales, by the way.
Which we're about to get to in one second.

Mary J. Blige, My Life.  That line, I know that things will turn out fine.  Yes, they would.  Yes, they would.  If you play it, I'll cry.  Because it brings me to that place where I was like... I didn't know if I was going to jail for 20 years.  I didn't know what my life was facing.  I got my two sons, I got my daughter, and I don't know what the is happening.  But I'm standing, and I'm handling it like a man.
